title: At-rest encryption for the Build Cache
body: Bitrise Build Cache protects customer data with at-rest encryption using envelope encryption and AES-256-GCM.

title: At-rest encryption for the Build Cache
body: Bitrise Build Cache protects customer data with at-rest encryption using envelope encryption and AES-256-GCM.

title: At-rest encryption overview
body: A unique Data Encryption Key (DEK) is generated for each customer.

title: At-rest encryption overview
body: The DEK is encrypted using a Key Encryption Key (KEK), which is generated and managed by a Key Management System (KMS). For example, Google KMS.

title: At-rest encryption overview
body: We rotate the KEK every 90 days for enhanced security.

title: At-rest encryption overview
body: The encrypted DEKs are stored securely in our database, but the DEK never persists in its decrypted formâ€”it is only used in memory when encrypting or decrypting data.

title: At-rest encryption overview
body: The DEK is used to encrypt customer data, ensuring that sensitive information is securely stored at rest.

title: At-rest encryption overview
body: KEK and DEKs are never stored together, ensuring strong isolation. The raw KEK is never exposed: it is only used within KMS to encrypt and decrypt DEKs securely. This approach ensures strong encryption, safe key handling, and a high level of data protection for our customers.

title: Security benefits
body: Strong encryption: AES-256-GCM is a widely trusted encryption standard that provides robust protection for sensitive data.

title: Security benefits
body: Customer isolation: Each customer has a unique DEK, meaning that if one customer's key were to be compromised, no other customers' data would be affected. Accessing encrypted data alone does not provide access to decrypted data.

title: Security benefits
body: Regulatory compliance: Our at-rest encryption aligns with best practices recommended by security and privacy regulations, including:

title: Security benefits
body: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation): Encourages encryption as a data protection measure.

title: Security benefits
body: CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act): Encrypted data may be exempt from certain breach liability requirements.

title: Security benefits
body: SOC 2: Supports encryption as a key security control for compliance.

title: Security benefits
body: ISO/IEC 27001: Recommends encryption for securing stored data.

title: Security benefits
body: NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology): Provides encryption standards (for example, AES-256) to ensure strong data protection and compliance with industry security frameworks.

title: Customer-managed Encryption Keys
body: For customers seeking greater control over their encryption, we offer the option to use Customer-Managed Encryption Keys (CMEKs).

title: Customer-managed Encryption Keys
body: With CMEKs, customers can store their Key Encryption Key (KEK) in their own Google Cloud KMS or Amazon KMS, allowing them to:

title: Customer-managed Encryption Keys
body: Maintain full control: Manage their own KEKs, including creation, rotation, and revocation.

title: Customer-managed Encryption Keys
body: Enhance security compliance: Ensure that only they have access to their encryption keys, aligning with strict internal security policies.

title: Customer-managed Encryption Keys
body: If you're interested in using CMEKs, contact us to discuss your requirements.

title: Gradle tasks and caching
body: In the Gradle build system, the basic unit of action is a task. A task could be compiling classes, running unit tests, or creating a JAR. Each task has its own inputs, such as files or environmental variables, and outputs.

title: Gradle tasks and caching
body: Tasks usually generate their output in a specific build directory which is configurable for each module. The contents of this directory can be often reused between builds on the same machine. As such, Gradle saves time by executing only the tasks that can't be reused. For other tasks, the output from the build directory is reused and the task gets the UP-TO-DATE label. This process is what Gradle calls an incremental build.

title: Gradle tasks and caching
body: Incremental build vs incremental task execution

title: Gradle tasks and caching
body: Incremental builds are not the same as incremental task execution! You can read about incremental tasks in Gradle's official docs.

title: Gradle tasks in a CI environment
body: When running Gradle in a CI environment, all tasks are either executed or retrieved from cache because the build directory is empty. After execution, Gradle saves metadata about the task inputs in the project cache directory. Gradle uses this metadata to be able to perfom incremental builds.

title: Gradle tasks in a CI environment
body: For example, in the case of a compile task, Gradle saves the checksum of the source files and only re-compiles files that have changed, based on the checksums. For more information on how Gradle checks task inputs, read Gradleâ€™s docs on task inputs and outputs.

title: Gradle tasks in a CI environment
body: If metadata is not available, Gradle will execute all tasks.

title: Caching tasks
body: If the metadata indicates that a task has to be executed, and the Bitrise build cache is enabled, the task inputs and certain Gradle properties such as the version are hashed into the cache key. If either the remote or local cache has a match for the cache key, the task does not have to be fully executed: its execution result is loaded from the cache and gets the FROM-CACHE outcome label.

title: Caching tasks
body: If there is no match for the cache key in the remote or local cache (a cache miss), the task is fully executed and its outputs are stored in the cache.

title: Caching tasks
body: When a task doesn't have the UP-TO-DATE label, the reasons for this are recorded and displayed in the task's row in the invocation details on Bitrise. Some of the possible reasons are as follows:

title: Caching tasks
body: Tasks without the UP-DO-DATE label can still be cached if their inputs were cached at least once previously.

title: Gradle dependency verification
body: Gradle dependency verification requires every plugin and dependency be listed in the Gradle project's verification metadata XML file. If any plugins or dependencies aren't listed, Gradle will exit with an error listing the relevant plugins and dependencies.

title: Gradle dependency verification
body: The Bitrise Build Cache uses two custom Gradle plugins:

title: Gradle dependency verification
body: The Bitrise Build Cache Gradle plugin implements Gradle's build cache interface.

title: Gradle dependency verification
body: The Bitrise Gradle Analytics Gradle plugin implements a build event listener.

title: Gradle dependency verification
body: The Build Cache for Gradle Step generates the necessary Gradle .init file which specifies these two plugins and the necessary initialization configuration. When this file exists in Gradle's .init.d directory, Gradle will automatically use the specified configuration. This conflicts with the dependency verification feature, as these plugins aren't listed in the metadata XML file.

title: Configuring the Build Cache with dependency verification
body: To be able to use the Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle with dependency verification, you need to:

title: Configuring the Build Cache with dependency verification
body: List the Bitrise plugins and their dependencies in the project's verification-metadata.xml file.

title: Configuring the Build Cache with dependency verification
body: Lock the Build Cache for Gradle Step to the latest patch version. Locking the Step to a specific version prevents automatic updates so the builds will always use the same version of the Step. For more information, check out Using a specific Step version.

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: The collected metadata in the metadata XML file differs from what Gradle expects in your environment.

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: Lock the Build Cache for Gradle Step to the latest version in your configuration YAML file.

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: Open the dependency matrix and find the CLI version corresponding to the Step version you locked in.

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: On your development machine or on Bitrise in a separate (non-production) Workflow, install that version of the CLI: replace CLIVERSION in the below curl command with the version you want to install, for example, v0.15.9.

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: curl --retry 5 -sSfL 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-build-cache-cli/main/install/installer.sh' | sh -s -- -b /tmp/bin -d "CLIVERSION"

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: Back up $HOME/.gradle/init.d/bitrise-build-cache.init.gradle.kts as the next step in the process will overwrite it.

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: Run the Bitrise CLI's gradle-verification add-reference-deps command:

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: /tmp/bin/bitrise-build-cache gradle-verification add-reference-deps

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: In your Gradle project folder, write the verification metadata. For example:

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: ./gradlew tasks --write-verification-metadata sha256

title: Generating and updating the verification metadata
body: Review the metadata differences and then commit and migrate your changes to your production Workflow.
